Dear Ms. Oom:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
April 29, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of ISEP
and/or policy. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Repeat violations must include an explanation of why the previous
corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(2) The foster parent training plan shall provide for all of the
following:
(c) Not less than 6 hours of training annually for each
licensee after the time periods specified in subdivisions (b) of
this subrule.
One of six foster home files reviewed lacked documentation of a foster parent
obtaining six hours of annual training as required.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster homes.
One of six foster home files reviewed documented the foster home was in full
compliance, however one foster parent had not obtained six hours of annual training
as required.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(7) If any violations are cited and there is a signed corrective
action plan, all social service workers who have children placed
in the home shall be notified there is a corrective action plan
and what is required of the foster parent in that plan.
One of three foster home files reviewed where a special investigation was completed
lacked the foster parent’s signature on the corrective action plan.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent then the
reason why return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with
a relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R
400.12404(4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s
age, appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand,
which includes an explanation to all relevant parties as to
why the change is necessary.
4

(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
(h) The child’s new location and address.
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of
the following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of
the change, except when prior notification would
jeopardize the child’s care or safety. If prior notice
is not provided, then the agency shall notify the
foster parent, at the time of the change, why prior
notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights concerning
the change in placement.
Three of four open foster child files reviewed where a placement change occurred
lacked the Action Summary (DHHS-69) which would have captured the information
required in subsections (a) through (h).
Three of four open foster child files reviewed where a placement change occurred
lacked the Notification of Move (DHHS-30) notifying the caregiver in writing at least
14 days prior of a foster child being moved.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report dated 5/6/19, CAP approved 6/24/19
Renewal Inspection Report dated 4/20/18, CAP approved 5/30/18.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating
to the care of the child.
(f) All known behavioral problems of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment
for the foster child and the foster family, including

information about siblings who do not reside in the foster
home.

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.19 Assessments and Service Plans, Content
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Five of eleven open foster care files reviewed lacked the required signatures on the
parent agency treatment plans.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED- Previous citation 6.33
Interim Inspection Report dated 5/6/19, CAP approved 6/24/19
Renewal Inspection Report dated 4/20/18, CAP approved 5/30/18.
ISEP 6.22 Visits, Worker-Parent
(a) For each child in foster care with a permanency goal of
reunification, the child’s caseworker shall have face-to-face
contacts with the child’s parent(s) as follows:
(1) for the first month the child is in care, two face-to-face
contacts with each parent, at least one of which must
occur in the parent’s place of residence;
(2) for each subsequent month, at least one face-to-face
contact with each parent and phone contact as needed,
with at least one contact in each three-month period
occurring in the parent's place of residence.
In four of seven open foster care youth files reviewed, monthly face-to-face contact
with the parents were not documented as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED- Previous citation 6.40
Interim Inspection Report dated 5/6/19, CAP approved 6/24/19

FOM 722-8C Foster Care Parent-Agency Treatment Plan and Service
Agreement
Signatures
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the

FOM 722-6H Caseworker Contact
Caseworker contact with children in out of home placement.
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement Move
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts per
month with the child for the first two months following an initial
placement or a placement move. The first face-to-face contact
with the child must take place within five business days from the
date the case is assigned to the caseworker or within five
business days of the date of the placement move. At least one
contact each month must take place at the child’s placement
location. Each contact must include a private meeting between
the child and the caseworker; see Private Meeting in this item.
NOTE: A month is defined as 30 calendar days, unless otherwise
specified; for example, calendar month

The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in a
case, including:
 Child fatality.
 Change in caseworker or organization.
 Change in parent contact information.
 Foster care transfer to adoption.
 Change in placement.
 Temporary break from placement.
 Program or case closing.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Foster Home Renewal Report application sent date should be consistent with
the date the letter and application was provided to the foster parent.
 Technical assistance regarding corrective action plans were provided for
foster parents. The agency is requiring the foster parents to receive training,
or review policy. Discuss need for how to measure compliance in the home,
including home visits, increased supervision of the home.
 Communication Issuance 20-055 was provided and reviewed regarding the
need for relatives to continued to be explored for placements regardless of
the COVID-19.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 The facility was not in need of consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were zero incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency found the foster family in non-compliance and developed a corrective
action plan. The corrective action plan required the foster parents to review policy,
and complete additional trainings. Technical assistance was provided on continuous
monitoring and supervision of foster home to ensure compliance.
AND
10

The agency has submitted three acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The first was in response to the 2018
Interim Inspection Report.
The second was in response to Special Investigation 2019C0223058 where the
agency was found in non-compliance as they did not verify youth’s eligibility for
YAVFC and did not visit the youth in their place of residence each month. The
agency submitted a corrective action plan and have followed the requirements.
The third was in response to Special Investigation 2020C223028 where the
agency was found in non-compliance as they did not fully assess a relative
caregiver’s Child Protective Services(CPS) history. They agency was aware of this
mistake and had already developed a corrective action plan with second
confirmation of CPS history moving forward.
Interviews with staff occurred via telephone due to COVID-19. Staff reported overall
satisfaction with the Child Welfare program at DA Blodgett. Staff reported
management supports them by encouraging feedback, providing surveys and
generally wanting to improve programming. Newer staff felt the specific staff meeting
for newly hired staff were extremely beneficial. Staff also stated that the agency has
worked on uploading and reviewing requirements throughout the year, as opposed to
waiting until audit time. CHRI was observed via video conference to be stored
securely and a cross shredder was available on site for destruction when needed.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
Safety Alert #1
Concern: An eye bolt lock was observed on the outside of the bedroom door
Resolution: The youth residing in the bedroom were interviewed and reported that
they are not locked in the bedroom, but the lock is used to keep their bedroom door
shut so the four younger children do not go into their bedroom and get into their toys.
The family agreed to this safety plan where the door would only be locked when the
two older youth were not home and would never been locked if someone was in the
room.
11

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued
a renewal of their regular license.
